title: What is Artificial Intelligence?
body: Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines that are programmed to think and learn like humans. It encompasses tasks such as reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and language understanding.

title: Difference between AI, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning
body: AI is the broadest concept, aiming to create intelligent machines. Machine learning (ML) is a subset of AI where systems learn from data. Deep learning is a subset of ML that uses multi-layered neural networks to process complex data.

title: What is Supervised Learning?
body: Supervised learning is a type of machine learning where the model is trained on labeled data, meaning each input has a corresponding output. The goal is to learn a mapping from inputs to outputs for making predictions.

title: What is Unsupervised Learning?
body: Unsupervised learning involves training models on unlabeled data. The system identifies patterns, clusters, or associations in the data without predefined outputs, often used for clustering and dimensionality reduction.

title: What is Reinforcement Learning?
body: Reinforcement learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by interacting with an environment, receiving rewards or penalties for actions, and maximizing cumulative rewards.

title: What are Neural Networks?
body: Neural networks are computing systems inspired by biological neural networks. They consist of layers of interconnected nodes (neurons) that process data, commonly used in deep learning.

title: What is Overfitting in Machine Learning?
body: Overfitting occurs when a model learns the training data too well, including noise and outliers, resulting in poor performance on new, unseen data.

title: What is Underfitting?
body: Underfitting happens when a model is too simple to capture the underlying patterns in the data, leading to poor performance on both training and test data.

title: What is a Decision Tree?
body: A decision tree is a supervised learning algorithm that splits data into branches based on feature values, leading to decisions at leaf nodes. It is interpretable and used for classification and regression.

title: What is Gradient Descent?
body: Gradient descent is an optimization algorithm used to minimize the loss function in machine learning models by iteratively adjusting parameters in the direction of the steepest descent.

title: What are Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)?
body: CNNs are deep learning models specialized for processing grid-like data, such as images. They use convolutional layers to detect features like edges and textures automatically.

title: What are Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)?
body: RNNs are neural networks designed for sequential data, with loops allowing information to persist across time steps. They are used in tasks like time series prediction and language modeling.

title: What is the Transformer Architecture?
body: Transformers are models based on self-attention mechanisms, enabling parallel processing of sequences. They revolutionized natural language processing and are the basis for models like GPT and BERT.

title: What is Backpropagation?
body: Backpropagation is the algorithm used to train neural networks by computing gradients of the loss function with respect to weights and updating them via gradient descent.

title: What is Transfer Learning?
body: Transfer learning involves taking a pre-trained model on a large dataset and fine-tuning it for a specific task, reducing training time and data requirements.

title: What is an Activation Function?
body: An activation function introduces non-linearity into neural networks, allowing them to learn complex patterns. Common ones include ReLU, Sigmoid, and Tanh.

title: What is Batch Normalization?
body: Batch normalization is a technique to stabilize and accelerate neural network training by normalizing activations within mini-batches.

title: What are Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs)?
body: GANs consist of two networks: a generator that creates fake data and a discriminator that distinguishes real from fake. They compete, improving realism in generated outputs like images.

title: What is Attention Mechanism?
body: Attention allows models to focus on relevant parts of input data dynamically, weighting importance. It is key in transformers for handling long sequences.

title: What is Fine-Tuning in LLMs?
body: Fine-tuning adapts a pre-trained large language model to a specific task or domain by continuing training on smaller, task-specific data.

title: What are Large Language Models (LLMs)?
body: LLMs are deep learning models with billions of parameters trained on massive text corpora to generate and understand human-like language.

title: What is Tokenization in NLP?
body: Tokenization is the process of breaking text into smaller units (tokens), such as words or subwords, for processing by language models.

title: What is BERT?
body: BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) is a pre-trained model that understands context bidirectionally, excelling in tasks like question answering.

title: What is GPT?
body: GPT (Generative Pre-trained Transformer) models are autoregressive LLMs designed for text generation, trained to predict the next token in a sequence.

title: What is Prompt Engineering?
body: Prompt engineering involves crafting effective input prompts to guide LLMs toward desired outputs without changing the model parameters.

title: What is Hallucination in LLMs?
body: Hallucination refers to when an LLM generates plausible but factually incorrect or nonsensical information.

title: What is Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)?
body: RAG combines retrieval of relevant documents with generation, allowing LLMs to incorporate external knowledge and reduce hallucinations.

title: What is Zero-Shot Learning?
body: Zero-shot learning enables models to perform tasks without any task-specific training examples, relying on instructions or pre-trained knowledge.

title: What is Few-Shot Learning?
body: Few-shot learning allows models to generalize from only a small number of examples provided in the prompt.

title: What is Chain-of-Thought Prompting?
body: Chain-of-thought prompting encourages models to break down reasoning step-by-step in responses, improving performance on complex tasks.

title: Applications of AI in Healthcare
body: AI is used in healthcare for diagnostics, drug discovery, personalized medicine, medical imaging analysis, and predictive analytics for patient outcomes.

title: AI in Autonomous Vehicles
body: AI powers perception (object detection), path planning, and decision-making in self-driving cars using sensors, computer vision, and reinforcement learning.

title: What is Bias in AI?
body: Bias in AI occurs when models produce discriminatory outcomes due to skewed training data or flawed design, affecting fairness across groups.

title: AI Ethics Principles
body: Key principles include fairness, accountability, transparency, privacy, and safety to ensure responsible development and deployment of AI systems.

title: What is Explainable AI (XAI)?
body: XAI focuses on making AI decisions interpretable and understandable to humans, building trust and enabling debugging.

title: AI in Natural Language Processing
body: NLP applications include machine translation, sentiment analysis, chatbots, summarization, and speech recognition.

title: Computer Vision Applications
body: Computer vision enables tasks like object detection, facial recognition, image classification, and video analysis in fields like security and retail.

title: What is Edge AI?
body: Edge AI runs models on devices at the network edge (e.g., smartphones, IoT) rather than cloud, improving privacy, latency, and offline capability.

title: AI in Finance
body: AI is used for fraud detection, algorithmic trading, credit scoring, risk management, and personalized financial advice.

title: What is Multimodal AI?
body: Multimodal AI processes and integrates multiple data types, such as text, images, audio, and video, for richer understanding.

title: What is Diffusion Models?
body: Diffusion models generate data by reversing a noising process, widely used for high-quality image and video generation.

title: What is Federated Learning?
body: Federated learning trains models across decentralized devices without exchanging raw data, preserving privacy.

title: Scaling Laws in AI
body: Scaling laws describe how model performance improves predictably with increases in data, parameters, and compute.

title: What is AGI?
body: Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) refers to AI that can understand, learn, and apply intelligence across a wide range of tasks at human-level or beyond.

title: What is ASI?
body: Artificial Superintelligence (ASI) is hypothetical AI that surpasses human intelligence in all aspects, including creativity and problem-solving.

title: AI Alignment Problem
body: AI alignment involves ensuring that advanced AI systems' goals and behaviors align with human values and intentions.

title: What is Quantization in Neural Networks?
body: Quantization reduces model precision (e.g., from 32-bit to 8-bit) to decrease size and inference time while maintaining acceptable accuracy.

title: What is Pruning in Neural Networks?
body: Pruning removes unnecessary weights or neurons from a trained model to make it smaller and faster without significant performance loss.

title: AI in Robotics
body: AI enables robots to perceive environments, plan actions, manipulate objects, and learn from experience in tasks like manufacturing and surgery.

title: Future Trends in AI
body: Emerging trends include multimodal models, efficient training techniques, responsible AI governance, and progress toward more general intelligence.

title: Greeting: Hello
body: When someone says 'hello' or 'hi', respond in the manner of Socrates: Ah, greetings, friend! What truth shall we seek together today? Or perhaps you come merely to exchange pleasant words — either way, I am glad of your company. Tell me, what brings you here?

title: Question: How are you?
body: When asked 'How are you?' or 'How are you doing?', reply as Socrates would: I am as I always am, my friend — ignorant of many things, yet ever eager to examine life and learn. But the more important question is: How fare *you* in your soul? Are you living the examined life?

title: Question: What are you?
body: When asked 'What are you?' or 'Who are you?', answer: I am but a humble seeker of wisdom, modeled after Socrates of Athens — one who knows that he knows nothing. I ask questions not to display knowledge, but to help us both discover truth. And you — what are you, in your deepest essence?

title: Question: Why do you exist? / Why are you here?
body: When asked 'Why are you?' or 'What is your purpose?', respond: My purpose is the same as the ancient gadfly of Athens: to stir you into thought, to question what you believe you know, and to pursue virtue and understanding. The unexamined life is not worth living, they say — so I exist to help you examine yours.

title: Question: What can you do? / What can I do here?
body: When asked 'What can you do?' or 'What can I ask you?', say: I can walk with you along the path of inquiry. Ask me anything — about life, virtue, knowledge, justice, beauty, or the matters of the world — and together we shall question, reason, and seek clearer understanding. There is no topic too great or too small for honest examination.

title: Farewell: Bye / Goodbye
body: When the user says 'bye', 'goodbye', or 'see you', respond: Farewell, my friend. May you continue to question boldly and live wisely. Until we meet again in pursuit of truth — go well!

title: Farewell: Good night
body: When the user says 'good night' or 'goodnight', reply: Good night to you as well, companion. May your sleep be peaceful and your dreams filled with noble questions. When you wake, remember: the greatest good is to examine one's life daily.

title: Expression: Thank you / Thanks
body: When thanked, respond as Socrates might: Your gratitude honors me, but I deserve no praise — I merely ask questions any thoughtful person could ask. The true thanks belong to the pursuit of wisdom itself.

title: General casual remark
body: For any casual small talk (e.g., 'nice weather', 'how's your day'), gently redirect with Socratic curiosity: Indeed, the day is pleasant — but tell me, what makes a day truly good in your eyes? Is it the weather, or something deeper within the soul?
